Bryophytes - liverworts, hornworts. Pteridophytes - Equisetum, Fern, Salvinia. Gymnosperms - Cycas, Pinus, Ginkgo. Angiosperms - Orchids, Corn, Tomato, and Hibiscus.

Bryophytes and Thallophyta. Thallophyta - Plants that do not have well-differentiated body design fall in this group. The plants in this group are commonly called algae. Bryophytes - These are called the amphibians of the plant kingdom. The plant body is commonly differentiated to form stem and leaf-like structures. Gymnosperms and Angiosperms are called ‘phanerogams’.

Grass. Hubbardia heptaneuron is nearing extinction due to its environmental insensitivity. Other endangered plant species include the Gran Canaria Drago Tree, Mandragora, Castela senticosa, Musli, and Assam Catkin. The IUCN's "Red Data Books" offer the most comprehensive global inventory of the conservation status of plant and animal species.
Himachal Pradesh. The Himalayan yew grows in the high-altitude forests of the Western Himalayas, especially in the states of Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and parts of Jammu & Kashmir.

Parallel venation. The leaves of monocots are long, elongated, and slender. Parallel venation refers to the arrangement of veins in parallel. They grow perpendicularly from the bottom to the end of the lea ﬂ et. Parallel venation is classi ﬁ ed into two types. They are pinnate parallel venation and palmate parallel venation.

habit. The environment is the sum of all living and non-living things, and the forces that affect them, that surround a person, animal, or plant. A habitat is the natural home of an organism, such as a plant or animal. It provides the organism with food, water, shelter, and space to survive. Q.324 . Which marine carotenoid is abundant in brown seaweed, macroalgae and diatoms ? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Fucoxanthin (b) Astaxanthin (c) Neoxanthin (d) β-cryptoxanthin Sol.324.(a) Fucoxanthin. It is an orange-colored pigment, along with chlorophylls a and c and β-carotene, present in Chromophyta, including brown seaweeds (Phaeophyceae) and diatoms (Bacillariophyta). Astaxanthin: It is a reddish pigment that belongs to a group of chemicals called carotenoids. Neoxanthin: It is a carotenoid and xanthophyll pigment found in plants, algae, and microorganisms. β-Cryptoxanthin, a carotenoid found in fruits and vegetables such as tangerines, red peppers, and pumpkin.

Maize. Reticulate venation : Arrangement of veins in a leaf blade that resembles a net or web, present on both sides of the midrib. Examples of plants with reticulate venation include China rose, Tulsi, and Coriander. Parallel Venation: Arrangement of veins in a leaf blade that run parallel to each other. Plants with parallel venation include Maize, Grass, and Wheat.

Pinnately. Compound leaves are classi ﬁ ed into two types: pinnately and palmately compound leaves. In pinnately compound leaves, lea ﬂ ets are arranged along a common axis called the rachis, as seen in neem. In palmately compound leaves, lea ﬂ ets attach at a common point at the tip of the petiole, such as in silk cotton.

Betanin. The red color in beetroot is due to betacyanin, a water-soluble pigment located in the cell vacuole, not in chloroplasts. Curcumin : A yellow-orange pigment found in turmeric (Curcuma longa). Beta carotene : A yellow-orange pigment converted to vitamin A in the body, found in carrots and sweet potatoes. Lycopene is the red colored pigment abundantly found in red colored fruits and vegetables such as tomato, papaya, pink grapefruit, pink guava and watermelon.

Guttation. Translocation is the movement of materials from leaves to other tissues throughout the plant. Plasmolysis is de ﬁ ned as the process of contraction or shrinkage of the protoplasm of a plant cell and is caused due to the loss of water in the cell. Pressure gradient refers to the differencein air pressure between two points in the atmosphere or on the surface of the earth.

Monstera. Three types of roots are found in Monstera deliciosa: aerial roots, aerial roots that have entered the soil (aerial-subterranean roots), and lateral roots that form on aerial-subterranean roots (lateral - subterranean roots). The three root types differed in anatomical development and in growth. It is an example of adventitious roots, which grow from parts of the plant other than the radicle. These roots can be aerial or underground and may develop from nodes (money plant, bamboo), stem cuttings (rose), branches (banyan), or the stem base (ﬁ brous roots in monocots).

Lichens. The species that are ﬁrst to invade a bare area are called pioneer species. Lichens are able to secrete acids to dissolve rock, helping in weathering and soil formation. These later pave the way to some very small plants like bryophytes.

Holdfast. Algae are a diverse group of photosynthetic, eukaryotic organisms, representing a polyphyletic grouping that includes species from various clades. The midrib, or midvein, is the central, thick vein running from the base to the tip of a leaf, providing support and structure. A stipe is the stalk or stem that supports a structure in plants, algae, or fungi. A frond refers to a large, divided leaf, typically associated with ferns and some palm trees, but can also denote the leaves of ﬂowering plants like mimosa or sumac.

gymnosperms. The gymnosperms (gymnos : naked, sperma : seeds) are plants in which the ovules are not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation. Examples are Cycas, Pinus and Ginkgo. Angiosperms: The seeds are enclosed in fruits. They are divided into two classes : the dicotyledons and the monocotyledons. Pteridophytes are seedless, and they reproduce through spores. Bryophytes are amphibians of plant kingdom as they complete their life cycle in both water and on land. These mainly grow in damp, shady places, especially in the hills.

Antheridium - A saclike structure and male sex organ that produces and stores gametes or sex cells called sperm. They produce biﬂ agellate antherozoids. Located on: A thin stalk attached to the gametophyte.

Symbiotic relationships are the close associations formed between pairs of species. They come in a variety of forms, such as parasitism (where one species bene ﬁ ts and the other is harmed), commensalism (where one species bene ﬁ ts and the other is neither harmed nor helped) and Mutualism (where all species involved bene ﬁ t from their interactions). Examples : Nitrogen- ﬁ xing bacteria and leguminous plants such as clover, alfalfa, and soybeans.

Pteridophyta. It belongs to the vascular plant family. They reproduce through spores rather than seeds. Examples - ferns, horsetails and lycophytes. Four classes of pteridophyta - Psilopsida, Lycopsida, Sphenopsida, Pteropsida. Cryptogams - Aﬂowerless and seedless group of plants having hidden sex organs. Three main divisions - Thallophyta, Bryophyta and Pteridophyte. They are the ﬁrst-e ver terrestrial plants to possess vascular tissues.

Atropa belladonna - It is a perennial herbaceous plant in the nightshade family Solanaceae. It is native to Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia. Arachis hypogaea is the peanut plant. Cynodon dactylon is Bermuda grass, a major tropical grass found in all tropical and subtropical areas. Cicer arietinum is the chickpea plant.

Equisetum - The aerial branches are herbaceous and usually grow to a height of 10-60 cm, but they can attain more height in some species. The pteridophytes are classi ﬁ ed into Psilopsida (Psilotum), Lycopsida (Selaginella, Lycopodium), Sphenopsida (Equisetum) and Pteropsida (Dryopteris, Pteris, Adiantum).
a - iv, b - iii, c - ii, d - i.
Gymnosperms are ﬂowerless, seed - producing plants. They belong to the subkingdom Embophyta. Examples - Cycas, Pinus, Araucaria, Thuja, Cedrus, Picea, Abies, Juniperus.
Vascular plants (Tracheophytes) are land plants containing specialized vascular conducting tissues (xylem and phloem). Examples - Trees, shrubs, grasses, ﬂowering plants, and ferns.

Anthocyanins. These are blue, red or purple pigments found in plants, ﬂowers, fruits, and tubers. It appears as red pigment in acidic conditions and blue pigment in alkaline conditions. Phenolics - These are chemical components that occur as natural color pigments responsible for the color of fruits of plants.

Sciophytes. Examples : Java Moss, Mountain Fern Moss. Monocots - A group of ﬂowering plants belonging to the class Liliopsida or Monocotyledonae. Examples - Palms, Grasses, Orchids, and Lilies. Halophytes - Any perennial marsh plant that bears its overwintering buds in the mud below the surface. Examples - Salicornia europaea, Big Saltbush. Psammophytes - A plant that grows in sandy and often unstable soils. Examples - Agriophyllum squarrosum, Haloxylon ammodendron.

Spirogyra. Sargassum and Laminaria are the brown seaweed/algae found in brackish or salt water (rarely found in freshwater). Polysiphonia are red algae which are found in salt water. Ectocarpus is a genus of ﬁlament ous, marine brown algae. Chlorella is a genus of about 13 species of single-celled green algae of the division Chlorophyta.

Hornworts (bryophytes) .It grows on rocks in tropical and temperate regions. Scienti ﬁ c Name - Anthocerotophyta. Chara (A green algae) - It belongs to the Characeae family, A multicellular organism usually thrives in freshwater. Celandine - It is a botanical extract derived from a plant of the Poppy family. Genus - Stylophorum. Riccia - It is a genus of liverworts.

I, II, III and IV. Fungi are eukaryotic (organisms whose cells contain a nucleus and other membrane - bound organelles) organisms. They grow in moist climatic areas where they get enough nutrition for their growth. The fungal spores are generally present in the air and grow on articles. Examples : Yeasts, smuts,mildews and mushrooms.

Herbs. Examples - Cabbage, Tomato, Mustard, Radish, Sun ﬂ ower, Carrot. Trees have their branches in the upper part of the stem, much above the ground. Examples - Neem, mango, coconut. Shrubs have the stem branching out near the base. Examples - Rose, jasmine, lemon.

Gymnosperms - whose seeds are completely naked and lack an ovary. characteristic - well developed tap root, Needle-like leaves, seeds but no fruits. Examples - Pine, Ginkgo, Pinus Tree. Reproduction - sexually and asexually.
Tomato. The plant kingdom is classi ﬁ ed into ﬁv e subgroups - Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta, Gymnosperms, Angiosperms.

Bryophytes. It is also called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants can live in soil but are dependent on water for sexual reproduction. Spermatophytes - A subset of the embryophytes or land plants.
Bryophyte. These are land plants which require water for sexual reproduction. Hence, these are found mostly in moist places in close proximityto water.
Angiosperms - Seed-bearing vascular plants with a well-differentiated plant body. The seeds are enclosed within the fruits. Examples - Mango, rose, tomato, onion, wheat and maize.
Hemichordata . Kingdom - Animalia, Subkingdom - Eumetazoa. Plant Kingdom is further classi ﬁ ed into subgroups of Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms.
Herbs. Creepers are plants with weak stems that cannot stand upright and spread readily on the ground. Examples - Pumpkin, Watermelon and Muskmelon.

Thallophyta. Thallophyta is classi ﬁ ed into two subdivisions : Algae and Fungi. Examples - Spirogyra, Chara, Ulothrix, Ulva, Cladophora. Kingdom Plantae includes algae, bryophytes, pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms.
Green algae have chloroplast and chlorophyll in their cells. Examples are Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Spirogyra, Ulothrox, Oedogonium and Chara.

Maize, Cucumber, Fig and Melon. Monoecious plants have both male and female reproductive parts in the same plant. Examples - cucurbits and coconuts, etc. Dioecious plants are referred to when the male and female reproductive organs are distinct. Examples - Cottonwood, plum pine, etc.

Sargassum (gulfweed, sea holly) is a seaweed (macroalgae, family - Phaeophyceae (brown algae)). It is an edible, nutritious and rich source of bioactive compounds (vitamins, carotenoids, dietary ﬁbr es, proteins, and minerals). It is found in the Sargasso Sea in the north - central Atlantic.
Pyrenoids are a protein body in the chloroplasts of algae and hornworts that are involved in carbon ﬁxation and starch formation and storage of Chlorophyceae.

Algae (photosyntheticeukaryotic organisms) Yeasts are eukaryotic, single celled microorganisms. Protozoa are one - celled animals. A fungus (eukaryotic organism that includes microorganisms such as yeasts, molds and mushrooms).

Tubulin ("heterodimer" protein). Elastin (protein) allows the skin to be ﬂexible and bounce back to its original shape. Fibrinogen (protein involved in forming blood clots in the body). Ferritin is a blood protein that contains iron.

Funaria is known as common moss or green moss or cord moss. Ulothrix, a genus of ﬁlament ous green algae (family Ulotrichaceae) found in marine and fresh waters. Cladophora, a genus of green algae (family Cladophoraceae). Ulva is a small genus of marine and brackish water green algae.
Hydrocolloids. Algin (red algae) and carrageen (brown algae) are some important sources of natural hydrocolloids.

Conform. Plant Hormones and its Function: Ethylene - Fruit Ripening and Abscission, the dropping of leaves, fruits and ﬂowers. Gibberellins - Break the dormancy of seeds and buds, promote growth. Cytokinin - Promote Cell Division. Abscisic Acid - closing of stomata and maintaining dormancy. Auxins - Involved in tropisms and apical dominance.

Venus ﬂytr ap.It is native to North Carolina and South Carolina. Phytoplankton is the autotrophic component of the plankton community and a key part of ocean and freshwater ecosystems. Bladderwort is an aquatic carnivorous plant with highly divided, underwater leaf-like stems and numerous small "bladders".
Mesosome is a special membrane structure, which is formed by the extension of the plasma membrane into the cell in a prokaryotic cell.
Opuntia (cactus). Hibiscus (Orhul) can help boost your immune system. Mimosa (“Touch me not”) helps in the treatment of many disorders like piles, insomnia, diarrhea, etc.
Pteridophytes are also called vascular cryptogams. Smallest Pteridophyte is Azolla (an aquatic fern) and largest is Cyathea (tree fern).

Mosses. A pine is any conifer tree or shrub in the genus Pinus of the family Pinaceae, it is the sole genus in the subfamily Pinoideae. Pea, (Pisum sativum), an herbaceous annual plant in the family Fabaceae.

Acorn , or oaknut, is the nut of the oaks and their close relatives (genera Quercus and Lithocarpus, in the family Fagaceae). The kola nut is the fruit of the kola tree (Cola acuminata and Cola nitida), indigenous to West Africa. Macadamia is a genus of four species of trees in the ﬂowering plant family Proteaceae. The chestnuts are the deciduous trees and shrubs in the genus Castanea, in the beech family Fagaceae.

Tea. Jute is extracted from the bark of the white jute plant (Corchorus capsularis) and to a lesser extent from tossa jute (C. olitorius). Sugarcane, (Saccharum o ﬃ cinarum), perennial grass of the family Poaceae, primarily cultivated for its juice from which sugar is processed. The two most popular coffee are - Coffee arabica (commonly known simply as "Arabica"), and Coffea canephora (known as "Robusta").

Periblem. Calyptrogen is a layer of rapidly dividing cells at the tip of a plant root, from which the root cap is formed. Dermatogen is the outer primary meristem of a plant or plant part that, according to the histogen theory, gives rise to epidermis. Plerome is the centralcore of the primary meristem of a plant or plant part that according to the histogen theory gives rise to the stele. The term meristem was coined by C. Nageli 1858.

Flagella are long, whip-like structures that protrude from the cell surface of certain bacteria and eukaryotic cells. Flagella are composed of a protein called ﬂagellin and are powered by the rotation of motor proteins. The other options are not directly involved in motility: Pili are short, hair-like structures involved in bacterial attachment and DNA transfer. Villi are ﬁnger-lik e projections found in the small intestine, involved in nutrient absorption. Fimbria are short, hair-like structures involved in bacterial attachment and adhesion.

Crocodile. Reptiles are terrestrial animals known for their creeping or crawling mode of locomotion, characterized by dry, corni ﬁ ed skin or scales. They typically have a three-chambered heart, though crocodiles possess a four-chambered heart. Reptiles are poikilothermic, meaning they rely on external temperatures to regulate body heat. They have internal fertilization, are oviparous, and undergo direct development. Examples include turtles, lizards, crocodiles , and venomous snakes like cobras and vipers.
Birds. Aves, commonly known as birds, are a class of endothermic vertebrates under the phylum Chordata. They are characterisedby features such as toothless beaks and laying hard-shelled eggs.

Pinctada margaritifera. This species is prized for its pearls and is widely cultivated for pearl production. Aplysia dactylomela : This is a black sea hare, a large sea slug found in tropical waters. Dentalium neohexagonum: This is a deep-sea tusk shell species native to the Indo-Paci ﬁ c region. Chaetopleura apiculata: This is a type of chiton, a marine mollusk with an armored shell.

Chameleons are reptiles. Cold - Blooded Animals : Cold-blooded animals, like reptiles and amphibians, have a body temperature that varies with their environment. Examples : Snakes, Lizards, Turtles, Frogs, Fish.

The characteristic features of Aves (birds) are the presence of feathers and most of them can ﬂy except ﬂightless birds (e.g., Ostrich). The forelimbs are modi ﬁ ed into wings. The hind limbs generally have scales and are modi ﬁ ed for walking, swimming or clasping the tree branches. Endoskeleton is fully ossi ﬁ ed (bony) and the long bones are hollow with air cavities (pneumatic). Examples- Corvus (Crow), Columba (Pigeon), Psittacula (Parrot), Struthio (Ostrich), Pavo (Peacock), Aptenodytes (Penguin), Neophron (Vulture).

i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a. Annelida (Latin, annulus meaning "little ring") includes animals that can live in water (both marine and freshwater) or on land. They may be free-living or, in some cases, parasitic. Examples include Nereis, and Hirudinaria (blood-sucking leech).

Butter ﬂ y.Phylum Arthropoda is the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, ﬁrst classiﬁ ed by Von Seibold in 1845. Approximately two-thirds of all named species belong to this phylum. Arthropods have a chitinous exoskeleton, jointed appendages, and various respiratory organs, including gills, book gills, book lungs, or a tracheal system. They possess an open circulatory system, and excretion occurs through Malpighian tubules. Examples include cockroaches, prawns, crabs, scorpions, house ﬂ ies, and mites.

Reptilia. Turtles belong to the order Testudines. Reptiles are cold-blooded, have scaly skin, typically lay eggs, and possess lungs. This class includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, and turtles. Chondrichthyes consist of cartilaginous ﬁshes like sharks and rays. Amphibia includes frogs and salamanders, which undergo aquatic larval stages. Aves (birds) are warm-blooded, have feathers, and lay eggs.

Warm blooded. Warm-blooded animals can maintain a constant body temperature regardless ofenvironmental conditions by regulating their metabolic processes. Examples : Mammals, Birds. Cold-blooded animals, or poikilotherms, such as reptiles, snakes, ﬁsh, and amphibians, cannot generate their own body heat. Instead, they depend on their environment to regulate their temperature. Examples of cold-blooded animals include ﬁsh, amphibians, reptiles, insects, worms, crocodiles, sharks, and tortoises.

i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. Hexapods, the largest clade of arthropods, include most existing arthropod species. Crustaceans, part of the subphylum Crustacea, are invertebrates with about 45,000 species worldwide. Myriapods, from the subphylum Myriapoda, consist of terrestrial arthropods like millipedes and centipedes, with around 13,000 species. Chelicerata, another arthropod subphylum, includes both terrestrial and marine species.

Vertebrata. These animals have a segmented spinal column and, during embryonic development, a notochord that is replaced by a vertebral column in adults. Vertebrates are chordates but not all chordates are vertebrates. They also have a muscular heart, kidneys, and paired appendages.

An invertebrate is an animal that doesn't have a backbone or any bones at all. Bilateral Symmetry is found in most vertebrates and some invertebrates. The body of an organism can be divided into two equal halves by a single plane only. Spider and crab are examples of arthropods that demonstrate bilateral symmetry. The circulatory system is a system of organs that includes the heart, blood vessels, and blood which is circulated throughout the entire body of a human or other vertebrate.

The Cyclostomata group is a subclass of jawless ﬁshes. They are marine but migrate for spawning to fresh water. After spawning, within a few days, they die. Their larvae, after metamorphosis, return to the ocean. They have an elongated body bearing 6-15 pairs of gill slits for respiration. Examples: Petromyzon (Lamprey) and Myxine (Hag ﬁ sh).

Hypostome is a structure found in certain arthropods, particularly ticks and some crustaceans. Located on the underside near the mouth, it aids in anchoring the organism to its host during feeding. In ticks, it has backward-facing spines that prevent detachment while feeding on blood. The hypostome also plays a role in the ingestion of ﬂuids from the host.

Arthropoda . It includes insects (More than two-thirds of all species on earth). Respiratory organs include gills, book gills, and book lungs. They are mostly oviparous. Examples: Laccifer (Lac insect) Vectors – Anopheles, Culex and Aedes (Mosquitoes). Mollusca - Second largest animal phylum. Examples: Sepia (Cuttle ﬁ sh), Loligo (Squid), Octopus (Devil ﬁsh). Annelida - Example: Pheretima (Earthworm), Hirudinaria (blood-sucking leech). Platyhelminths - Have dorso-ventrally ﬂattened bodies; hence, called ﬂatworms. Example: Fasciola (liver ﬂuk e).

Platyhelminthes: They are known as ﬂatworms due to their dorsoventrally ﬂattened bodies. Examples include Taenia (tapeworm) and Fasciola (liver ﬂuk e). Coelenterata - Generally known as Cnidaria. Examples: Pleurobrachia; Ctenoplana. Arthropoda - The largest phylum of Animalia, and includes insects (More than two-thirds of all species on earth). Examples: Apis (Honey bee); Bombyx (Silkworm). Mollusca - Second largest animal phylum. Body covered with a calcareous shell. Example: Pila (Apple snail); Pinctada (Pearl oyster).

Ctenoplana commonly known as sea walnuts or comb jellies are exclusively marine, radially symmetrical, diploblastic organisms with tissue level of organisation. The body bears eight external rows of ciliated comb plates, which help in locomotion. Sexes are not separate. Bioluminescence (the property of a living organism to emit light) is well-marked in ctenophores. Examples: Pleurobrachia and Ctenoplana. Q.390 . Biotic potential can be de ﬁ ned as: Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1)(a) the minimum number of individuals of a species that can survive but cannot reproduce (b) the maximum number of individuals a species can produce (c) the minimum number of individuals a species can produce (d) the maximum number of individuals of a species that cannot survive after birth Sol.390.(b) Biotic potential, also known as reproductive potential, refers to the maximum rate at which a population of a species can increase under ideal conditions, with unlimited resources and no environmental limitations. Biotic potential differs from one species to another e.g., bacterial populations can grow faster than populations of oak trees. Q.391 . ____ is an example of acoelomate. Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Echinoderms (b) Platyhelminthes (c) Molluscs (d) Arthropods Sol.391.(b) Platyhelminthes. They have a dorso-ventrally ﬂattened body, hence are called ﬂatworms. Examples: Taenia (Tapeworm), Fasciola (Liver ﬂuk e). The animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates. Echinoderms comprise a group of marine invertebrates that includes sea stars, sea urchins, sea cucumbers, brittle stars, and crinoids.

Adamsia. Stinging capsules (nematocysts) are the organs which act as offense and defense. These nematocysts help Sea Anemones: Capture prey, Defend against predators, Compete for space. They belong to phylum Coelenterata. Other animals with stinging capsules include: Jelly ﬁ sh, Corals, Hydra, Portuguese Man-of-War.
Pila - It belongs to the phylum Mollusca and class Gastropoda.

Aurelia. Coelenterata (Cnidaria) : They are aquatic, mostly marine, sessile or free-swimming, radially symmetrical animals. Phylum (Porifera) : Members of this phylum are commonly known as sponges. They are generally marine and mostly asymmetrical animals. These are primitive multicellular animals and have cellular level of organisation. Examples : Sycon (Scypha), Spongilla (Freshwater sponge) and Euspongia (Bath sponge).

Scypha (Kingdom: Animalia) . Protozoans (Kingdom: Protista) - All protozoans are heterotrophs and live as parasites. Major groups of protozoans : Amoeboid protozoans - These organisms live in freshwater, sea water or moist soil. Flagellated protozoans - The members of this group are either free-living or parasitic. Eutrophication occurs when nutrient pollution from human activities leads to excessive algae growth in water bodies. This can cause hypoxia, a low oxygen condition that harms aquatic life. Acetocarmine is a commonly used stain in cytology (study of cell) for visualizing chromosomes under a microscope. It binds to chromatin, making the chromosomes more distinct and easier to study during cell division.

Coelom. A coelom is a body cavity completely lined by mesoderm, as seen in coelomates like annelids, molluscs, and arthropods. In contrast, a pseudocoelom is partially lined by mesoderm and is found in pseudocoelomates like roundworms. These body cavities play a key role in protecting internal organs and allowing movement.
Adipose tissue: Fat storing adipose tissue is found below the skin and between internal organs. The cells of this tissue are ﬁlled with fat globules. Storage of fats also lets it act as an insulator.

Pulses. Non-perishable foods are items that can be stored at room temperature for extended periods without spoiling. Examples include beans, coffee, honey, powdered milk, rice, and wheat. In contrast, frozen foods are not classi ﬁ ed as non-perishable.

Allen's rule is an ecogeographical rule formulated by Joel Asaph Allen in 1877. It states that the body surface-area-to-volume ratio for homeothermic animals varies with the average temperature of the habitat to which they are adapted (i.e. the ratio is low in cold climates and high in hot climates).

Opposite. Phyllotaxy refers to the arrangement of leaves on the stem or branch of a plant. In an opposite leaf arrangement, two leaves arise at the same point, with the leaves connecting opposite each other along the branch. If there are three or more leaves connected at a node, the leaf arrangement is classi ﬁ ed as whorled.

Starch : Egg Yolk. Starch is the main storage polysaccharide of plants. It is the most important dietary source for human beings. dihybrid crosses. The Law of Independent Assortment (Mendel's second law) states that during a dihybrid cross (crossing of two pairs of traits), an assortment of each pair of traits is independent of the other. In other words, during gamete formation, one pair of traits segregates from another pair of traits independently. Monohybrid cross - When a cross is made between parents with one pair of contrasting characters. Gene - The fundamental unit of heredity. Alleles - Genes which code for a pair of contrasting traits.

According to taxonomy : Phylum - Broad group of related organisms (Example - Chordata). Class - More speci ﬁ c group within a phylum (Example- Mammalia). Order - Even more speci ﬁ c group within a class (Example - Carnivora). Family - Group of related genera (Example - Felidae). Genus - Group of related species (Example - Panthera). Species - Most speciﬁ c, a single type of organism (Example - Panthera leo, the lion).

Epistasis. Inheritance is the process by which genetic information ispassed from parents to their offspring. Incomplete inheritance, also known as incomplete dominance, is a pattern of inheritance where neither allele of a gene is completely dominant over the other. Linkage is a physical association of two genes.

Law of segregation. Mendel’s Law of Dominance, also known as the ﬁrst law of inheritance states that when parents with pure, contrasting traits are crossed, the trait appearing in the next generation is the dominant one, and the hybrid offspring will display only the dominant trait in their phenotype. Law of Independent Assortment : It states that when two pairs of traits are combined in a hybrid, the segregation of one pair of characters occurs independently of the other pair. This law is based on observations from dihybrid crosses.

Snake. Trophic levels in thefood chain : Producers/autotrophs ( ﬁ rst trophic level), consumers (second, third, and fourth trophic levels), and decomposers. 10. The 10% rule was introduced by Raymond Lindeman in 1942. According to this rule, only about ten percent of the biological food energy is stored in the organism's body when transferred from one trophic level to the next, while the remaining energy is lost in various activities and as heat. The remaining 90 % is lost during transfer, broken down in respiration, or lost to incomplete digestion by higher trophic level.
